title: New Brunswick will put its own price on carbon following federal election result
text:
Premier Blaine Higgs said he will look at a new consumer-focused measure to replace the federal pricing system, which applies in provinces that do not have their own policies. “People voted for it, so we have to find a way in New Brunswick to make it work,” he told reporters. (CBC)

Talking point: As in Ontario, the New Brunswick government had launched a campaign of stickering gas-station pumps with information about the effects of Ottawa’s tax, without mentioning the included consumer rebates. But unlike Ontario, Manitoba and Saskatchewan, New Brunswick didn’t launch a court challenge against the measure. Higgs was the only premier who opposed the federal carbon price to reverse course. Ontario Premier Doug Ford congratulated Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and said his government would “continue to discuss” its efforts to fight the tax as it evaluated the election result. Alberta Premier Jason Kenney was due to speak later Tuesday. However, the election result led Saskatchewan Premier Scott Moe to retrench on the issue, tweeting an open letter that called on Trudeau to “cancel the federal carbon tax” right away. The federal Liberals lost their only seat in Saskatchewan on Monday, but held onto six of 10 in New Brunswick.
